<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/33 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 359, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 1 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> October/November 2024 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 419, 222, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 890, 606]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 649]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 730, 682]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 720, 905, 852]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[66, 102, 84, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 102, 630, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the resistivity of a metal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 133, 487, 152]]<|/det|>
Set up the circuit shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 170, 705, 408]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 426, 591, 445]]<|/det|>
**Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 176, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 457, 888, 476]]<|/det|>
The distance between the two crocodile clips is \(L\). The reading on the voltmeter is \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 488, 771, 508]]<|/det|>
Adjust the position of crocodile clip F so that \(L\) is approximately \(45 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 521, 176, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 521, 339, 540]]<|/det|>
Close the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 552, 176, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 552, 611, 570]]<|/det|>
Record the value of \(L\) and the voltmeter reading \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 612, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 643, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
<form>V = .................................................... $V$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 176, 693]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 675, 336, 693]]<|/det|>
Open the switch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 688, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Vary \(L\) in the range \(15.0 \text{cm} \leqslant L \leqslant 95.0 \text{cm}\) by adjusting the position of F. For each position of F, measure \(L\) and \(V\). Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(L\) and \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 732, 141]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{1}{L}\) and \(\frac{1}{V}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 523, 920, 541]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 553, 144, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 551, 176, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 546, 643, 576]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{V}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{L}\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 552, 920, 571]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 584, 180, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 583, 457, 603]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 584, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 615, 180, 634]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 615, 608, 634]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 831, 918, 850]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 861, 918, 880]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 878, 920, 897]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 72, 737, 92]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 92, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 630, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the movement of a ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 801, 152]]<|/det|>
You are provided with two table tennis balls A and B, each attached to a string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 430, 183]]<|/det|>
The mass of A and its string is \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 416, 214]]<|/det|>
Use the balance to measure \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 225, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
<form>m = ....................................................... $g$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[918, 225, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 146, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 257, 176, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 257, 603, 275]]<|/det|>
Attach the clamp to the stand using the boss.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 288, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
Place both strings between the two wooden strips and secure the wooden strips in the clamp, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 327, 855, 664]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 676, 591, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label> (not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 707, 215, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 707, 920, 757]]<|/det|>
Adjust the apparatus so that the bottoms of the two wooden strips are approximately \(50 \text{cm}\) above the bench and the bottoms of the two balls are approximately \(1.5 \text{cm}\) above the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 218, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>EITHER</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Displace A and adjust the position of the block so that, when they are touching, the centre of A is level with the top of the block, as shown in Fig 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 114, 759, 361]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 371, 591, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 402, 215, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>EITHER</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 402, 920, 437]]<|/det|>
When A is in this position, the distance between the centre of B and the bench is \(b\), as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 448, 740, 467]]<|/det|>
The distance between the top of the block and the bench is \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 479, 473, 497]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(b\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 509, 920, 529]]<|/det|>
<form>b = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 540, 920, 559]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 573, 215, 591]]<|/det|>
<label>EITHER</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 573, 381, 591]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(\sqrt{d - b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 588, 438, 606]]<|/det|>
Give an appropriate unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[510, 651, 920, 670]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\sqrt{d - b} =\) ....................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 668, 917, 687]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 700, 180, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 700, 890, 718]]<|/det|>
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your value of \(\sqrt{d - b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 794, 920, 812]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 72, 220, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 546, 88]]<|/det|>
Release A so that it moves towards B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 102, 210, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>·</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 102, 529, 120]]<|/det|>
When A hits B, it causes B to move.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 133, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
At the maximum height of ball B, the vertical distance between the centre of B and the bench is \(H\), as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 175, 745, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 433, 591, 452]]<|/det|>
<center>Fig. 2.3 (not to scale)</center>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 464, 346, 482]]<|/det|>
Determine \(H\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 555, 920, 574]]<|/det|>
<form>H = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 560, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 588, 180, 606]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 588, 816, 606]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(H\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 727, 920, 745]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... %

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 758, 181, 777]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 758, 920, 777]]<|/det|>
With this arrangement of the apparatus, the total mass of A is equal to \(m\) measured in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 789, 475, 808]]<|/det|>
Record the total mass \(M\) of A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 819, 920, 836]]<|/det|>
<form>M = ....................................................... $

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 850, 384, 868]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(\sqrt{H - b}\) .

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 911, 920, 930]]<|/det|>
\[\sqrt{H - b} = \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \dots \quad [1]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 698, 89]]<|/det|>
Use the adhesive putty to attach the \(10.0 \text{g}\) slotted mass to A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 102, 900, 120]]<|/det|>
The total mass \(M\) of A is now equal to the sum of \(m\) and the mass of the slotted mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 178, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
Displace A and adjust the position of the block so that, when they are touching, the centre of A is level with the top of the block, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 180, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 406, 199]]<|/det|>
Repeat (b)(iii) and (b)(v).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 272, 920, 289]]<|/det|>
<form>H = ....................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 333, 920, 351]]<|/det|>
<form>M = ....................................................... $g$

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[504, 395, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
\[\sqrt{H - b} = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 146, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 683, 462]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(H\), \(b\), \(m\), \(M\) and \(d\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[396, 473, 601, 504]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{\sqrt{H - b}} = k + \frac{m}{2M\sqrt{d - b}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 339, 527]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 540, 505, 559]]<|/det|>
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 744, 920, 762]]<|/det|>
<form>first value of \(k =\) ......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 776, 920, 793]]<|/det|>
<form>second value of \(k =\) ......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 791, 920, 809]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 185, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 71, 910, 88]]<|/det|>
